qas.question: What word means that ceramics don't absorb liquids?
What materials do glass ceramics have a lot in common with?
What word means that ceramics don't absorb crystalline?
What materials do test regimes have a lot in common with?

plausible_answers.text: a non-crystalline intergranular phase of grain boundaries

qas.question: What is water often embedded within?
What are permeability materials formed as?

context: Glass-ceramic materials share many properties with both <a2_0><b5_0>non-crystalline glass and crystalline ceramics<b5_0/><a2_0/>. They are formed as a <b7_0>glass<b7_0/>, and then partially crystallized by <a1_0><b4_0>heat treatment<b4_0/><a1_0/>. For example, the microstructure of whiteware ceramics frequently contains both amorphous and crystalline phases. Crystalline grains are often embedded within <b6_0>a non-crystalline intergranular phase of grain boundaries<b6_0/>. When applied to whiteware ceramics, <a0_0><b3_0>vitreous<b3_0/><a0_0/> means the material has an extremely low permeability to liquids, often but not always water, when determined by a specified test regime.
